questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis with a history of fever for 4 days and erythematous rashes on the chest. There was no history of travel and tick bite. His CSF findings showed increased protein, normal glucose, mild lymphocytosis and few RBCs. Which of the following is the most likely organism to cause this clinical picture? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Enterovirus

questions.text: There are 3 to 5% healthy hepatitis B carriers in India who are asymptomatic. They are at the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma in the future because? (INICET NOV 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: They are unable to mount inflammation against the virus

options.label: B
options.text: Virus can integrate with host DNA and form complementary DNA

options.label: C
options.text: There is a risk of elevation of transaminases

options.label: D
options.text: Liver parenchymal cells are in a state of high proliferation

questions.correct_answer: B. Virus can integrate with host DNA and form complementary DNA
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Virus can integrate with host DNA and form complementary DNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatitis B virus can integrate its DNA into the host genome, leading to genetic mutations and increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A female patient presents with swollen Bartholin glands. Discharging pus showed Gram-negative intracellular diplococci. Which is the organism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a Gram-negative intracellular diplococcus, is the causative agent of gonorrhea and can infect the Bartholin glands, leading to swelling and pus discharge.

questions.text: Which medication is used to treat an infection caused by the cestode egg of the given organism? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Praziquantel

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Praziquantel is the medication used to treat infections caused by the cestode egg of Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm). The eggs are colorless, almost transparent, and immediately infective when shed in stool. Praziquantel effectively treats this infection with a single dose of 5-10 mg/kg.

questions.text: Viral infection mimicking erythroblastosis fetalis is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Parvovirus B19

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parvovirus B19 infection can uniquely mimic erythroblastosis fetalis by causing severe fetal anemia and related complications through its direct impact on erythroid progenitor cells. Awareness of this potential complication is essential, particularly in pregnant women, as the infection can lead to significant fetal outcomes, necessitating careful monitoring and management.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy developed severe headache, fever, and altered mental status after swimming in a warm freshwater lake. CSF examination showed motile trophozoites with round nucleus. Identify the causative organism: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of acute meningoencephalitis following freshwater exposure, along with motile trophozoites in CSF, is characteristic of Primary Amebic Meningoencephalitis (PAM) caused by Naegleria fowleri. This free-living amoeba enters through the nasal route during swimming and reaches the brain through the cribriform plate. The trophozoites show rapid directional movement and contain a single round nucleus.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Acanthamoeba castellanii: Causes chronic granulomatous amebic encephalitis (GAE) primarily in immunocompromised hosts, and keratitis in contact lens users. Does not present with acute onset after swimming.
  • • Option A) Acanthamoeba castellanii:
  • • Option C) Entamoeba histolytica: Causes intestinal and extraintestinal amebiasis. Does not invade CNS or cause meningoencephalitis.
  • • Option C) Entamoeba histolytica:
  • • Option D) Hartmannella vermiformis: A free-living amoeba that rarely causes human disease. Not associated with CNS infections.
  • • Option D) Hartmannella vermiformis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand the distinct clinical presentations and epidemiology of free-living amoebae:
  • ➤ N. fowleri: Acute PAM after freshwater exposure Acanthamoeba: Chronic GAE in immunocompromised, keratitis in contact lens users Routes of entry and tissue tropism differ among these organisms
  • ➤ N. fowleri: Acute PAM after freshwater exposure
  • ➤ Acanthamoeba: Chronic GAE in immunocompromised, keratitis in contact lens users
  • ➤ Routes of entry and tissue tropism differ among these organisms

questions.text: What is the causative organism for the condition shown in the image below? ( INICET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Echinococcus granulosus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The condition shown in the image, characterized by a hydatid cyst in the liver, is caused by Echinococcus granulosus. The cysts contain internal daughter cysts and can lead to symptoms related to the pressure effect on the liver and biliary system.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about cutaneous anthrax, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Wool Sorter's disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cutaneous anthrax is an infection caused by the bacterium Bacillus anthracis. The infection typically begins as a small papule at the site of spore entry through the skin. This papule then develops into a painless vesicle and subsequently forms a characteristic black necrotic eschar. The term "malignant pustule" is often used to describe the severe appearance of the lesion. Additionally, cutaneous anthrax is sometimes referred to as "Hide Porter's disease" because it was historically common among workers handling hides and skins.
  • • Wool Sorter's disease: This term refers to pulmonary anthrax, not cutaneous anthrax. Pulmonary anthrax was historically common among workers inhaling dust from infected wool, hence the name.
  • • Wool Sorter's disease:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A . Malignant pustule: This term correctly refers to the lesion of cutaneous anthrax, highlighting its severe and threatening appearance before the advent of antibiotics.
  • • Option A
  • • Malignant pustule:
  • • Option B . Hide Porter's disease: This is another name for cutaneous anthrax, historically common among dock workers handling hides and skins.
  • • Option B
  • • Hide Porter's disease:
  • • Option C . Black eschar: This is a hallmark of cutaneous anthrax, describing the coal-black necrotic lesion that forms as the infection progresses.
  • • Option C
  • • Black eschar:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • "Wool Sorter's disease" refers to pulmonary anthrax, not cutaneous anthrax.

questions.text: The following image is caused by infection with which virus? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CMV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Owl's eye inclusion bodies, which are intranuclear basophilic inclusions, are characteristic of CMV infection. This feature helps distinguish CMV from other viral infections in histopathological examinations.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain since 4 days with a history of remitting fever and bradycardia after having meals outside frequently. Which test can be done in the patient to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Blood culture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In suspected cases of typhoidal salmonella presenting within the first week of symptoms, a blood culture is the most appropriate diagnostic test.

questions.text: The following tzanck smear finding is seen in? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HSV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tzanck smears are useful for diagnosing skin infections caused by herpes viruses, including HSV-1 and HSV-2. The presence of multinucleated giant cells with ground-glass chromatin is a hallmark of HSV infection.

questions.text: The presence of antibodies against SARS CoV2 in the blood likely indicates? ( INICET MAY 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Previous infection even if patient has been asymptomatic

options.label: D
options.text: That the patient is in window period

questions.correct_answer: A. Previous infection even if patient has been asymptomatic
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Previous infection even if patient has been asymptomatic

questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following? ( INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) RNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ SNoW - DRoP:-
  • ➤ SOUTHERN - DNA NORTHERN - RNA WESTERN - Protein
  • ➤ SOUTHERN - DNA
  • ➤ NORTHERN - RNA
  • ➤ WESTERN - Protein

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis, and the CSF sample was subjected to gram staining and microscopy and appears as shown in the microscopic image given below. Which of the following features/tests will be characteristic of the organism? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Oxidase and catalase negative, does not ferment inulin

options.label: B
options.text: Ferments glucose and maltose but not inulin

options.label: C
options.text: Oxidase and catalase positive and does not ferment maltose or glucose

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Catalase negative, optochin sensitive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Streptococcus pneumoniae , a common cause of bacterial meningitis, is characterized by being catalase-negative, optochin-sensitive, and gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci. These features help in its identification and differentiation from other bacterial pathogens.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dimorphic fungus? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pneumocystis jirovecii

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Pneumocystis jirovecii is not a dimorphic fungus
  • ➤ Dimorphic fungi:
  • ➤ Dimorphic fungi:
  • ➤ Blastomyces dermatitidis Histoplasma capsulatum Paracoccidioides brasiliensis Penicillium marneffei Sporothrix schenckii Coccidioides immitis Coccidioides posadasii
  • ➤ Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • ➤ Histoplasma capsulatum
  • ➤ Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  • ➤ Penicillium marneffei
  • ➤ Sporothrix schenckii
  • ➤ Coccidioides immitis
  • ➤ Coccidioides posadasii

questions.text: What is the incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 10-30 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is 10-30 days. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3, and primarily affects the lymphatic system. Diagnosis is based on serological tests or identification of the bacteria in clinical specimens through various methods.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ascaris lumbricoides

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine, identifiable by its large size, cylindrical shape with tapered ends, and characteristic mouth with three finely toothed lips.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with left-sided flank pain. A CT scan was done which is shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Cyst contents can produce anaphylactic reaction

options.label: C
options.text: A segmented dog tapeworm is the causative agent

options.label: D
options.text: FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy

questions.correct_answer: D. FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Hydatid disease, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by cyst formation in organs such as the liver, lungs, and kidneys. FNAC or biopsy should not be done in cases of suspected hydatid cysts due to the risk of anaphylaxis and dissemination of the infection.

questions.text: A patient presents with episodic swelling and inflammation of eyelids with subconjunctival nodules. Blood smear shows sheathed microfilaria with nuclei extending to the tip of the tail. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of eye involvement with subconjunctival nodules, along with sheathed microfilaria having nuclei extending to the tail tip, is characteristic of Loa loa infection (African eye worm). Loa loa microfilariae are sheathed and have nuclei that extend to the tip of the tail, distinguishing them from other filarial worms.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Wuchereria bancrofti: Causes lymphatic filariasis with lower limb edema. Its microfilariae are sheathed but lack nuclei at the tail tip.
  • • Option A) Wuchereria bancrofti:
  • • Option C) Brugia malayi: Also causes lymphatic filariasis. Its microfilariae are sheathed but have two distinct terminal nuclei at the tail tip.
  • • Option C) Brugia malayi:
  • • Option D) Mansonella perstans: Microfilariae are unsheathed and have nuclei extending to the tail tip but don't cause eye manifestations.
  • • Option D) Mansonella perstans:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand distinctive features of different microfilariae:
  • ➤ Loa loa: Sheathed, nuclei to tail tip, eye manifestations W. bancrofti: Sheathed, no tail nuclei, lymphatic symptoms B. malayi: Sheathed, two terminal nuclei, lymphatic symptoms M. perstans: Unsheathed, blunt tail with nuclei
  • ➤ Loa loa: Sheathed, nuclei to tail tip, eye manifestations
  • ➤ W. bancrofti: Sheathed, no tail nuclei, lymphatic symptoms
  • ➤ B. malayi: Sheathed, two terminal nuclei, lymphatic symptoms
  • ➤ M. perstans: Unsheathed, blunt tail with nuclei

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mucor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucor is identified by broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide-angle branching, and it typically lacks rhizoids, unlike Rhizopus which has nodal rhizoids.

questions.text: A person arrived with a lesion on their left buttock. This individual has a past medical record of undergoing a heart transplant 15 years ago. Analysis of the fluid extracted from the lesion reveals the presence of gram-positive filamentous bacteria. What is the probable microbial agent responsible for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nocardia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Nocardia is a gram-positive, branching filamentous bacillus, particularly seen in immunocompromised patients, and can be identified using modified acid-fast staining.

questions.text: Delayed hypersensitivity is due to? ( INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Interferon gamma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Interferon gamma is the key cytokine responsible for mediating delayed hypersensitivity reactions by activating macrophages and enhancing their pathogen-killing capabilities.

questions.text: Oxidase positive Gram-negative bacilli that do not show colored colonies on MacConkey media? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pseudomonas is an oxidase-positive Gram-negative bacillus that does not produce colored colonies on MacConkey agar because it is a lactose non-fermenter. On MacConkey agar, lactose non-fermenting bacteria produce colorless colonies since they do not ferment lactose to produce acid.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Shigella: Shigella is oxidase-negative and does not ferment lactose, producing colorless colonies on MacConkey agar.
  • • Option A. Shigella:
  • • Option B. Salmonella: Salmonella is oxidase-negative and does not ferment lactose, resulting in colorless colonies on MacConkey agar.
  • • Option B. Salmonella:
  • • Option C. Proteus: Proteus is oxidase-negative and does not ferment lactose, hence it forms colorless colonies on MacConkey agar.
  • • Option C. Proteus:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Pseudomonas is an oxidase-positive, lactose non-fermenting Gram-negative bacillus that forms colorless colonies on MacConkey agar.

questions.text: A man presents with the following lesion after traumatic inoculation. Identify the causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sporothrix schencki

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sporothrix schenckii, the cause of sporotrichosis, typically presents as a chain of nodular and ulcerating lesions along lymphatic channels following traumatic inoculation, earning it the name "Rose Gardener's Disease."

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cytomegalovirus is the leading cause of infection in renal transplant recipients during the first four months post-transplantation, showcasing the importance of monitoring and managing CMV to prevent its common presentations and complications in this vulnerable period.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents with frothy, foul-smelling vaginal discharge and pruritus. Microscopic examination of the discharge shows characteristic motile organisms. Identify the causative organism: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The microscopic examination shows motile organisms characteristic of Trichomonas vaginalis. T. vaginalis is a protozoan that causes trichomoniasis, presenting with frothy, malodorous vaginal discharge, vulvar irritation, and pruritus. On wet mount microscopy, the organisms show characteristic jerky motility with flagellar movement.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Shows non-motile Gram-negative diplococci on microscopy. Usually presents with purulent cervicitis or urethritis.
  • • Option A) Neisseria gonorrhoeae:
  • • Option C) Gardnerella vaginalis: Associated with bacterial vaginosis, showing "clue cells" on microscopy without motility. The discharge is typically thin, grey, and homogeneous with a fishy odor.
  • • Option C) Gardnerella vaginalis:
  • • Option D) Candida albicans: Shows pseudohyphae and budding yeast cells on microscopy without motility. The discharge is typically thick, white, and cottage cheese-like.
  • • Option D) Candida albicans:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand the microscopic characteristics and clinical presentations of different organisms causing vaginal discharge, emphasizing the importance of correlating clinical features with microscopic findings for accurate diagnosis of sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes scombroid fish poisoning? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Scombroid fish poisoning is primarily caused by the decarboxylation of L-histidine into histamine by bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa in improperly stored fish, leading to a range of symptoms from mild gastrointestinal discomfort to severe allergic reactions.

questions.text: Microfilariae with sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Brugia malayi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The identification of microfilariae with a sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is a diagnostic feature of Brugia malayi, crucial for distinguishing it from other filarial infections. This morphological detail is important for correct diagnosis and appropriate management of lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A patient from a military background presented with rash, fever, and altered sensorium. There is also a deficiency of the membrane attacking complex. The likely cause can be: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitidis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with deficiencies in the membrane attack complex (C5-C9) of the complement system are particularly susceptible to infections caused by Neisseria species, such as Neisseria meningitidis, which can lead to severe conditions like meningococcemia.

questions.text: A child presents with a fever and a rash. Urine examination showed cells with owl's eye appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "owl's eye" appearance of cells in the urine is a diagnostic clue for Cytomegalovirus infection, especially relevant for diagnosing congenital CMV infections in neonates or severe infections in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who engaged in unprotected sexual intercourse develops urethral discharge one week later as shown in the given image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a significant cause of sexually transmitted infections, manifesting as acute urethritis with purulent discharge in males. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with appropriate antibiotics, such as a combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin, are crucial to prevent complications and limit the spread of this highly contagious infection.
  • ➤ Non-gonococcal urethritis is caused by:
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Chlamydia trachomatis ﻿﻿Ureaplasma urealyticum ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium ﻿﻿Trichomonas vaginalis ﻿﻿Herpes simplex virus (rare) ﻿﻿Adenovirus ﻿﻿Haemophilus vaginalis ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Chlamydia trachomatis
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Trichomonas vaginalis
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Adenovirus
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Haemophilus vaginalis
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium

questions.text: Which of the following life cycle is given below? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) E. Histolytica

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The life cycle of Entamoeba histolytica includes the motile trophozoite and the non-motile cyst stages, with transmission primarily by the fecal-oral route. The most frequent site of systemic disease caused by E. histolytica is the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Xenodiagnostic method? (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli

options.label: B
options.text: Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient

options.label: C
options.text: Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis

options.label: D
options.text: Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.correct_answer: B. Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Xenodiagnosis involves using a vector to ingest potentially infected tissue or fluids and then examining the vector for the presence of the pathogen, making it particularly useful in cases where direct detection of the pathogen is challenging due to low numbers.

questions.text: A patient presents with cervical lymphadenopathy and is found to be retropositive. A fungal culture depicts a velvety growth with red diffusible pigment on the underside, as shown below. Which is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Talaromyces marneffei

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Recognition of the red diffusible pigment in culture is critical in identifying Talaromyces marneffei infection, particularly in HIV-positive patients. It's important to consider this pathogen when patients from endemic regions present with systemic symptoms and lymphadenopathy. Treatment involves antifungal therapy tailored to the severity of the infection, with agents such as itraconazole for mild cases and amphotericin B for severe cases.

questions.text: A child presents with asymptomatic white nodules attached to hair shafts. Microscopy of the hair shows arthroconidia arranged in chains around the hair shaft. Identify the causative organism: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The microscopic findings describe white piedra, caused by Trichosporon beigelii. The characteristic feature is the presence of soft, white to light brown nodules composed of arthroconidia arranged in chains around (not within) the hair shaft. This is an ectothrix infection, where fungal elements are found outside the hair shaft.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Microsporum canis: Causes ectothrix infection with small spores arranged in a mosaic pattern around the hair shaft, associated with fluorescence under Wood's lamp.
  • • Option A) Microsporum canis:
  • • Option C) Malassezia furfur: Associated with pityriasis versicolor and seborrheic dermatitis, does not form nodules on hair shafts.
  • • Option C) Malassezia furfur:
  • • Option D) Trichophyton tonsurans: Causes endothrix infection with fungal elements within the hair shaft, not forming external nodules.
  • • Option D) Trichophyton tonsurans:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand different patterns of fungal hair infections:
  • ➤ Ectothrix: Fungal elements outside hair shaft (M. canis, T. beigelii) Endothrix: Fungal elements inside hair shaft (T. tonsurans) Nodular infections: White piedra (T. beigelii) vs Black piedra (Piedraia hortae)
  • ➤ Ectothrix: Fungal elements outside hair shaft (M. canis, T. beigelii)
  • ➤ Endothrix: Fungal elements inside hair shaft (T. tonsurans)
  • ➤ Nodular infections: White piedra (T. beigelii) vs Black piedra (Piedraia hortae)

questions.text: Outbreak of diarrhea. Rice water stool in nature. Pathogen exhibited darting motility. What is the organism? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vibrio cholerae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Types of motility:
  • ➤ Types of motility:

questions.text: A HIV patient with fever, chronic diarrhea presented to OPD. His stool was examined which showed the following oocysts. Identify the components used for staining the stool? (INICET MAY 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin

options.label: B
options.text: Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue

options.label: C
options.text: Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet

options.label: D
options.text: Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin

questions.correct_answer: B. Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain uses methanol for fixation, Kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin as the primary stain, acid alcohol for decolorization, and methylene blue as the counterstain to detect acid-fast organisms like Cryptosporidium parvum.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with history of fever and enlarged lymph nodes and sore throat was suspected to have infectious mono-nucleosis and was ordered a Paul Bunnel test. Which of the following is the principle of the test? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Heterophile antibody test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The Paul Bunnell test is a heterophile antibody test used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis. It detects IgM heterophile antibodies that can agglutinate sheep erythrocytes, which are present during the early stages of the infection.

questions.text: Vector for Scrub typhus / Orientia tsutsugamushi is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mite

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rickettsial diseases:
  • ➤ Rickettsial diseases:

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. Which of the following organism is most likely to cause these symptoms? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus aureus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with painless genital ulcer and regional lymphadenopathy 3 weeks after unprotected sexual intercourse. Microscopy shows spirochetes. The best culture medium for isolation of the causative organism is: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation suggests primary syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum. This organism cannot be cultured on artificial media. The only reliable method for maintaining and propagating T. pallidum is through rabbit testicular tissue culture (rabbit infectivity test), which remains the gold standard for maintaining viable organisms.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Thayer Martin agar: This is selective for Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which presents with purulent urethral discharge and dysuria, not with painless ulcers.
  • • Option A) Thayer Martin agar:
  • • Option C) MacConkey agar: This medium is used for enteric Gram-negative bacteria and cannot support the growth of fastidious organisms like T. pallidum.
  • • Option C) MacConkey agar:
  • • Option D) Blood agar: While this is an enriched medium, it cannot support the growth of T. pallidum, which requires living tissue for propagation.
  • • Option D) Blood agar:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand that some pathogenic organisms, particularly T. pallidum, cannot be cultured on artificial media and require specialized living tissue systems for propagation, emphasizing the unique diagnostic challenges in confirming syphilis infection.

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of high fever for 5 days and altered sensorium. On further probing, it was found that he had two seizures one day ago. Peripheral smear shows the following findings. How will you manage this patient? ( INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days

options.label: C
options.text: Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

questions.correct_answer: C. Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cerebral malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum is a medical emergency requiring prompt treatment with intravenous artesunate, which is the most effective and rapid-acting medication for severe malaria.

questions.text: A patient with prosthetic valve implantation, presented after six months with features of endocarditis. What could be the cause? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) S. epidermidis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Endocarditis is an infection of the inner lining of the heart, the endocardium, which often involves the heart valves. Prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) can be categorized into early-onset and late-onset based on the time of onset after surgery. Early-onset PVE occurs within one year of valve implantation, while late-onset occurs after one year.
  • • Staphylococcus epidermidis is a coagulase-negative staphylococcus and is a common cause of early-onset PVE due to its ability to form biofilms on prosthetic materials. Biofilms protect the bacteria from the host immune system and antibiotic treatment, making infections difficult to eradicate.
  • • Given that the patient developed endocarditis six months after prosthetic valve implantation, it falls under early-onset PVE. Therefore, the most likely causative organism is Staphylococcus epidermidis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Pseudomonas: While Pseudomonas can cause healthcare-associated infections, it is not a common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis.
  • • Option B. Pseudomonas:
  • • Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: This organism is a common cause of both native and prosthetic valve endocarditis, particularly in intravenous drug users and hospital-acquired cases. However, for early-onset PVE, Staphylococcus epidermidis is more typical.
  • • Option C. Staphylococcus aureus:
  • • Option D. S. saprophyticus: This organism is commonly associated with urinary tract infections and is not a typical cause of endocarditis.
  • • Option D. S. saprophyticus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Classification to diagnose causative organism of Endocarditis -
  • ➤ Classification to diagnose causative organism of Endocarditis -

questions.text: Assertion (A): Myocarditis is the common known complication of faucial diphtheria Reason (R) : It is due to bacteremia by diphtheria (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is false and reason is also true

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is true and reason is also false

questions.correct_answer: D. Assertion is true and reason is also false
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Assertion is true and reason is also false

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Assertion: Myocarditis is indeed a common and serious complication of diphtheria, especially in cases of faucial diphtheria. The diphtheria toxin can cause significant damage to the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis.
  • • Assertion:
  • • Reason: The assertion that myocarditis is due to bacteremia by diphtheria is incorrect. Diphtheria does not cause bacteremia. Instead, the complications, including myocarditis, are due to the exotoxin produced by the Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The toxin disseminates through the bloodstream, affecting various organs, including the heart, nerves, and kidneys.
  • • Reason:
  • • Diphtheria Toxin: The pathogenesis of diphtheria involves the production of diphtheria toxin, which is a potent exotoxin. This toxin, rather than the bacteria itself, enters the bloodstream (toxemia) and affects distant organs. Toxemia vs. Bacteremia: Diphtheria is characterized by toxemia, not bacteremia. The bacteria remain localized at the site of infection (e.g., the throat), but the toxin spreads systemically. Myocarditis as a Complication: The diphtheria toxin affects the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis, which is the most common and severe complication of diphtheria. Other complications include neuritis and damage to the adrenal glands.
  • • Diphtheria Toxin: The pathogenesis of diphtheria involves the production of diphtheria toxin, which is a potent exotoxin. This toxin, rather than the bacteria itself, enters the bloodstream (toxemia) and affects distant organs.
  • • Diphtheria Toxin:
  • • Toxemia vs. Bacteremia: Diphtheria is characterized by toxemia, not bacteremia. The bacteria remain localized at the site of infection (e.g., the throat), but the toxin spreads systemically.
  • • Toxemia vs. Bacteremia:
  • • Myocarditis as a Complication: The diphtheria toxin affects the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis, which is the most common and severe complication of diphtheria. Other complications include neuritis and damage to the adrenal glands.
  • • Myocarditis as a Complication:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason given is not the correct explanation.
  • • Option A. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion:
  • • Option B. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason itself is false.
  • • Option B. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion:
  • • Option C. Assertion is false and reason is also true: Incorrect because the assertion is true, but the reason is false.
  • • Option C. Assertion is false and reason is also true:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myocarditis is a common and serious complication of diphtheria due to the effects of the diphtheria toxin. It is important to recognize that the complications arise from toxemia, not bacteremia.

questions.text: A patient came with infective endocarditis. Examination showed gram-positive cocci in chains. What is the likely etiological agent? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Streptococcus viridans, an alpha-hemolytic streptococcus found in the normal oral flora, is a common cause of infective endocarditis, particularly in patients with underlying heart valve abnormalities or prosthetic heart valves. Its characteristic microscopic appearance of gram-positive cocci arranged in chains is a key diagnostic feature.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below. ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ig A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Secretory IgA is critical for mucosal immunity due to its unique structure and location. It acts as the first line of defence by preventing pathogens from adhering to and penetrating mucosal surfaces, thus playing a vital role in protecting the body from infections, especially at the mucosal barriers.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses exhibits genetic re-assortment similar to that of influenza virus? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Rotaviruses have a segmented RNA genome that allows them to undergo genetic reassortment similar to influenza viruses.

questions.text: A patient came with meningitis. His protein level was elevated and glucose level was normal. CSF examination showed lymphocytosis. What is the likely etiology? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with meningitis, the presence of lymphocytosis (elevated lymphocytes) in the CSF, along with an elevated protein level and normal glucose level, strongly suggests tuberculous meningitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: Type 2 lepra reaction is which type of hypersensitivity reaction? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type III

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Type 2 lepra reaction (also known as erythema nodosum leprosum, ENL) is mediated by a Type III hypersensitivity reaction. In this type of reaction:
  • • Immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) deposit in tissues, leading to complement activation and inflammation. This reaction occurs in lepromatous leprosy due to a sudden increase in circulating Mycobacterium leprae antigens that form immune complexes with antibodies. The immune complexes cause tissue damage, resulting in tender erythematous nodules, fever, and systemic inflammation. Key Features of Type III Hypersensitivity: Immune complex-mediated (IgG or IgM antibodies bind to soluble antigens). Complement activation and neutrophilic inflammation. Examples: Type 2 lepra reaction, serum sickness, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
  • • Immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) deposit in tissues, leading to complement activation and inflammation.
  • • This reaction occurs in lepromatous leprosy due to a sudden increase in circulating Mycobacterium leprae antigens that form immune complexes with antibodies.
  • • The immune complexes cause tissue damage, resulting in tender erythematous nodules, fever, and systemic inflammation.
  • • Key Features of Type III Hypersensitivity:
  • • Immune complex-mediated (IgG or IgM antibodies bind to soluble antigens).
  • • Complement activation and neutrophilic inflammation.
  • • Examples: Type 2 lepra reaction, serum sickness, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Type I Hypersensitivity:
  • • Option A) Type I Hypersensitivity:
  • • Mediated by IgE antibodies, causing mast cell degranulation. Seen in allergic reactions, anaphylaxis, and atopic conditions (e.g., urticaria, asthma).
  • • Mediated by IgE antibodies, causing mast cell degranulation.
  • • Seen in allergic reactions, anaphylaxis, and atopic conditions (e.g., urticaria, asthma).
  • • Option B) Type II Hypersensitivity:
  • • Option B) Type II Hypersensitivity:
  • • Involves cytotoxic antibodies (IgG or IgM) binding to cell-bound antigens, leading to cell destruction via complement or ADCC (antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity). Examples: Hemolytic anemia, Goodpasture syndrome, Rh incompatibility.
  • • Involves cytotoxic antibodies (IgG or IgM) binding to cell-bound antigens, leading to cell destruction via complement or ADCC (antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity).
  • • Examples: Hemolytic anemia, Goodpasture syndrome, Rh incompatibility.
  • • Option D) Type IV Hypersensitivity:
  • • Option D) Type IV Hypersensitivity:
  • • Cell-mediated immunity involving T-lymphocytes and macrophages. Delayed onset (48-72 hours) and seen in tuberculin skin tests, contact dermatitis, and granuloma formation. Type I lepra reaction (reversal reaction) is an example of Type IV hypersensitivity.
  • • Cell-mediated immunity involving T-lymphocytes and macrophages.
  • • Delayed onset (48-72 hours) and seen in tuberculin skin tests, contact dermatitis, and granuloma formation.
  • • Type I lepra reaction (reversal reaction) is an example of Type IV hypersensitivity.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type 2 lepra reaction (erythema nodosum leprosum) is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction caused by immune complex deposition. It presents with tender nodules, fever, and systemic inflammation and is commonly associated with lepromatous leprosy.

questions.text: The CLED medium is preferred over other media for the culture of organisms in case of UTI because: (INICET NOV 2019)

options.label: B
options.text: It promotes the growth of candida, streptococcus and staphylococcus

options.label: C
options.text: It differentiates between lactose-fermenting and non-lactose fermenting bacteria

options.label: D
options.text: It promotes the growth of pseudomonas

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. It inhibits proteus swarming

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystine-Lactose-Electrolyte-Deficient (CLED) medium is a differential medium used for the isolation and enumeration of bacteria from urine. The medium supports the growth of all urinary potential pathogens and provides distinct colony morphology. It supports the growth of urinary pathogens and contaminants and gives good colonial differentiation without the spread of Proteus species due to its lack of electrolytes.

questions.text: A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Leishmania tropica

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leishmania tropica is the causative agent of cutaneous leishmaniasis, leading to skin ulcers that can be identified by microscopy showing organisms with kinetoplasts. Awareness of this condition is crucial for correct diagnosis and management, particularly in endemic areas like parts of Rajasthan, India.

questions.text: A patient admitted with 50% burns develops an infection at the burn site. The swab was cultured, the isolate is a strict aerobe and the test that is shown in the image is positive. What is the likely etiology of the burn infection? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The identification of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in a burn wound infection is crucial due to its potential for rapid spread and resistance to treatment. Early detection and aggressive management are key to preventing severe complications such as sepsis or further tissue damage.
  • ➤ Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen. Enterobacteriacee (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.
  • ➤ Oxidase test
  • ➤ Oxidase positive organisms:
  • ➤ Oxidase positive organisms:
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Pseudomonas ﻿﻿Vibrio ﻿﻿Helicobacter ﻿﻿Campylobacter ﻿﻿Pasteurella ﻿﻿Legionella ﻿﻿Neisseria ﻿﻿Brucella ﻿﻿Moraxella ﻿Burkholderia
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Pseudomonas
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Vibrio
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Helicobacter
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Campylobacter
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Pasteurella
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Legionella
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Neisseria
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Brucella
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Moraxella
  • ➤ ﻿Burkholderia

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Legionella pneumonia is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Aspiration is an important mode of transmission

options.label: B
options.text: Legionella antigens in the urine is the gold standard of diagnosis

options.label: C
options.text: Legionnaires' disease is also known as Pontiac fever

questions.correct_answer: B. Legionella antigens in the urine is the gold standard of diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Legionella antigens in the urine is the gold standard of diagnosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Legionella pneumonia, caused by Legionella pneumophila, is diagnosed using a variety of methods. The urinary antigen test is a rapid, sensitive, and specific method for diagnosing Legionella infections, especially for Legionella pneumophila serogroup 1. While culture remains the definitive method, the urinary antigen test is often considered the gold standard in clinical settings
  • • Comparison of Diseases Caused by Legionella pneumophila
  • • Comparison of Diseases Caused by Legionella pneumophila
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Aspiration is an important mode of transmission : This is incorrect. While aspiration can be a mode of transmission, inhalation of contaminated water droplets is more common.
  • • Option A. Aspiration is an important mode of transmission
  • • Option C . Legionnaires' disease is also known as Pontiac fever : This is incorrect. Legionnaires' disease and Pontiac fever are two distinct forms of legionellosis. Legionnaires' disease is a severe form of pneumonia with systemic symptoms, while Pontiac fever is a milder, self-limiting, flu-like illness without pneumonia.
  • • Option
  • • . Legionnaires' disease is also known as Pontiac fever
  • • Option D. High person-to-person transmission : This is incorrect. Legionella does not typically spread from person to person. The primary mode of transmission is through the inhalation or aspiration of contaminated water droplets.
  • • Option D. High person-to-person transmission
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The urinary antigen test is a crucial diagnostic tool for Legionella pneumonia, providing a rapid and specific method for detecting Legionella pneumophila serogroup 1.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified under Biosafety level -3 infections? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) XDR-TB

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • XDR-TB (Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis) requires BSL-3 (Biosafety Level 3) containment due to its high risk of airborne transmission and severe disease potential.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Salmonella : Generally handled under BSL-2 due to lower risk.
  • • Option B. Salmonella
  • • Option C. Ebola : Handled under BSL-4, given its high risk and lethality.
  • • Option C. Ebola
  • • Option D. Congo Crimean Fever : Also requires BSL-4 due to high fatality rates and transmission risk.
  • • Option D. Congo Crimean Fever

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The classification of pathogens is according to biosafety levels. XDR-TB is managed under BSL-3 conditions due to its airborne risks and drug resistance challenges.

questions.text: A patient presents with gastrointestinal problems including abdominal pain and distension, bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea, and tenesmus, with rectal prolapse. A stool examination reveals the presence of typical barrel-shaped eggs. What is the possible causative agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Trichuris trichiura

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Table listing appearance of various organism in stool/sputum examination
  • ➤ Table listing appearance of various organism in stool/sputum examination

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the genital area and a painful vesicle on examination, accompanied by painful lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) HSV2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) typically presents with painful genital vesicles and can cause painful lymphadenopathy. HSV2 is a common cause of genital herpes and is known for causing recurrent outbreaks of painful vesicular lesions in the genital area.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Molluscum: Molluscum contagiosum causes painless, pearly papules, which are typically umbilicated. These lesions are not vesicular and do not cause painful lymphadenopathy.
  • • Option B. Molluscum:
  • • Option C. HPV: Human Papillomavirus infection results in the formation of warts, which are generally painless. HPV warts can appear on the genital area but do not present with vesicles or painful lymphadenopathy.
  • • Option C.
  • • HPV:
  • • Option D. HIV: Human Immunodeficiency Virus does not present with genital vesicles. HIV infection leads to systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and generalized lymphadenopathy, rather than localized painful vesicles in the genital area.
  • • Option D.
  • • HIV:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HSV2 infection is characterized by painful genital vesicles and can be associated with painful lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: Which immunoglobulin is elevated in a case of chronic allergy? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) IgE

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is correct regarding management in this case? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.correct_answer: A. Steroids followed by antiparasitic drugs
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Steroids followed by antiparasitic drugs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The management of neurocysticercosis involves administering steroids first to control inflammation, followed by antiparasitic drugs to target the larval infection, along with antiepileptic drugs to control seizures.
